text: Is there a paper on Catalyst.jl? I’m interested in reading more about it, or perhaps are there papers that inspired it that I could read?

text: I was hoping to read about accuracy (numerical integration vs. the ML model integration)… and just about techniques. I can probably get all of that from the docs. It’s sciml so are you using neural odes to parametrize the rhs and then integrating that?

elements.text: I was hoping to read about accuracy (numerical integration vs. the ML model integration)… and just about techniques. I can probably get all of that from the docs. It’s sciml so are you using neural odes to parametrize the rhs and then integrating that?

text:
I see that it passes to `ODEProblem()` and everything just works with that of course. Very Julia : ) Here are more refined questions…
1. Do you have any performance plots or results (like above)
2. Has there been any thought on converting the rhs to a less stiff set of ODEs? This is of course hard to do in general, but since everything is coupled in a unique way, I’ve heard about how it might be possible. Ex if there are two terms that are orders of magnitude bigger than all the other terms but effectively cancel each other out. Maybe this isn’t so much a reaction network thing but a stiff ode thing, but I was just wondering if anyone had worked on it.

text: Ok, thanks for the info! The reason I ask is the biggest bottle neck for nuclear astro codes is the huge ode solve for reactions you have to do at every step of the hydro and a collaborator at LBL recently has been training PINNS to do this and he’s shown it provides a promising speed up. It’d be cool to incorporate all of the cool julia tools into it.

elements.text: Ok, thanks for the info! The reason I ask is the biggest bottle neck for nuclear astro codes is the huge ode solve for reactions you have to do at every step of the hydro and a collaborator at LBL recently has been training PINNS to do this and he’s shown it provides a promising speed up. It’d be cool to incorporate all of the cool julia tools into it.
